_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FLINT HILLS RESOURCES - Port Arthur Chemicals (PAC) - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

 

2.1    Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

The Executive Summary gives an overview of each of the components of the Risk Management Program, including:



?    A narrative on the accidental release prevention and emergency response policies as required by 40 CFR 68.155(a);

?    A description of the stationary source and regulated substances handled as required by 40 CFR 68.155(b);

?    A section on general accidental release prevention and chemical-specific prevention steps as required by 40 CFR 68.155(c);

?    the Five-Year Accident History of the facility as required by 40 CFR 68.155(d);

?    A description of the emergency response program as required by 40 CFR 68.155(e); and

?    A discussion of planned changes to improve safety as required by 40 CFR 68.155(f).  



It should be noted that the Executive Summary no longer includes a discussion of the Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios reported to the EPA due to regulations promulgated on April 9, 2004.



The Executive Summary included in RMP*eSubmit is shown in its entirety below.

2.1.1    Introduction and Policies

Flint Hills Resources Port Arthur, LLC (FHR) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  FHR's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 



The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety

at the plant.





2.1.2    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Port Arthur Complex (PAC or the "facility"), operated by Flint Hills Resources Port Arthur, LLC (FHR), is an olefins plant with the capacity to produce nearly 1.4 billion pounds per year of ethylene and 700 million pounds per year of chemical-grade propylene, which are both sold into the merchant market with pipeline access to many major delivery points in the U.S. Gulf Coast and the lower Mississippi River regions. Ethylene and propylene are basic chemical building blocks used to manufacture a variety of products such as trash bags, automotive parts, and medical devices. 



The facility consists of four main processes:

1.    Light Olefins Unit (LOU),

2.    Aromatics Unit/Cyclohexane Unit (AU/CU),

3.    Utilities operation, and

4.    Offsite Tankage operation 



There are approximately 28 EPA RMP regulated substances used at the facility in amounts greater than the threshold quantity; the facility is in NAICS code 32511 and is subject to the OSHA process safety management standard, 29 CFR 1910.119. Consequently, the facility is regulated under the Program Level 3 requirements.





2.1.3    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by FHR.  These high standards include:



?    Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 

?    Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.

?    Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.

?    Correcting findings identified in regular audits of the facility.



2.1.4    Prevention Program

The PAC Olefins Plant is operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ong

oing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety have contributed to process safety and the facility has only one  RMP chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:



?    Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in power supply to the process control system by having a backup power generator.

?    Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.

?    Minimizing the possibility of a release of propylene with shutdown interlocks installed on process equipment.

?    Reducing the severity of fires with operation of automatic sprinkler and manual deluge systems.

?    Reducing the risk of overfilling by having level alarms and/or indicators on the storage tank.

?    Implementing operating procedures for unloading and transfer operations.

?    Installing combustible gas detectors in the facility.





2.1.5    Five-Year Accident History

    Within the last five years (April 2008 - April 2013), there have been no releases of hazardous materials that resulted in onsite injuries, death or offsite impacts. However, there was one incident in 2011 that did result in on-site property damage. Details are shown in the table below.

    

Table 1:  Incident Summary

Item    Incident Description

Plant Incident #:    49563

Unit #:    74829 - Light Olefins Unit (LOU)

Date of Incident:    05/23/2011

Time of Incident:    10:45 PM

NAICS #:    32511

Chemical Released:    Flammable Mixture

Amount of Chemical Released:    22,346 lbs

Resulted in (evacuation, unit shutdown, mutual aid response, significant damage, etc.):    Shutdown and Evac. Unit, 

Pump fire with $968,242 in property damage incurred

Wind Speed (mph):    16 mph

Wind Direction:    SSE

Ambient

Temperature (oF):    79

Atmospheric Stability (overcast, low or high clouds, sunny):    Class D

Raining (or other precipitation):    No

Include copy of investigation report with root cause and contributing factors?    Equipment Failure, Human Error

Offsite Impact (evacuation, shelter in place, damage, etc.)?    None

    

    

2.1.6    Emergency Response Program

    The facility continues to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate emergency response actions necessary with the local Port Arthur Fire Department.  As appropriate, also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the local Port Arthur Police Department, State Police, and other coordinating agencies, and local hospitals.  The PAC facility Plant Manager and Plant Safety Manager are responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A written and specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.





2.1.7    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

    Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

    

?    The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of changes made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.

?    The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure 

timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.

?    The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.



Specific actions at PAC that will be taken in the future to improve the

level of safety at the facility include:



?    Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.

?    An ongoing dialogue with the Port Arthur Fire and Police departments and other emergency responders to ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.  The facility coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
